title: Gas clouds circling black holes in opposite directions could help them grow rapidly
text:
Unstable gas clouds circling black holes in opposite directions may help them grow more rapidly because they get sucked in faster, a new study suggests.

Researchers came to this conclusion after observing such counter-rotating clouds in the distant galaxy NGC 1068, which was analysed using radio telescopes in Chile.

The findings may explain how supermassive black holes — which existed even in the young universe — can develop in such short time frames.

NGC 1068 — also known as Messier 77 — is a spiral galaxy that lies around 47 million light years from the Earth, out in the direction of the constellation Cetus.

It centre is active — containing a supermassive black hole that is continuously feeding from its surrounding, rotating disk of dust and gas.

Previous observations revealed that the hole is also spewing out gas at speeds more than one million miles per hour (around 1.6 million kilometres per hour).

This gas hides the black hole from optical telescopes — meaning that radio telescopes are needed to get a good look at it.

Unstable gas clouds circling black holes in opposite directions may help them grow more rapidly because they get sucked in faster, a new study suggests. Pictured, the gas clouds orbiting the supermassive black hole that lies at the heart of the galaxy NGC 1068

Astronomer Violette Impellizzeri of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Charlottesville, Virginia and colleagues used the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) to conduct a detailed study of NGC 1068.

'Thanks to the spectacular resolution of ALMA, we measured the movement of gas in the inner orbits around the black hole,' said Dr Impellizzeri.

'Surprisingly, we found two disks of gas rotating in opposite directions.'

The inner disk is around 2–4 light years in width and rotates in the same direction as the surrounding galaxy.

In contrast, the larger outer disk — which spans around 4–22 light years — revolves in the opposite direction.

'We did not expect to see this, because gas falling into a black hole would normally spin around it in only one direction,' explained Dr Impellizzeri.

'Something must have disturbed the flow, because it is impossible for a part of the disk to start rotating backward all on its own.'

Such counter-rotational flows are not an uncommon phenomena in space.

'We see [them] in galaxies, usually thousands of light-years away from their galactic centres," said paper co-author and astrophysicist Jack Gallimore, of the Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania.

'The counter-rotation always results from the collision or interaction between two galaxies.'

'What makes this result remarkable is that we see it on a much smaller scale, tens of light-years instead of thousands from the central black hole.'

Astronomer Violette Impellizzeri of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Charlottesville, Virginia and colleagues used the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) to conduct a detailed study of NGC 1068, pictured

In the case of NGC 1068, the researchers believe that the backward flow might have been formed from a small, passing galaxy that got captured in the disk, or alternatively from clouds that fell out of the galaxy.

'Counter-rotating gas streams are unstable, which means that clouds fall into the black hole faster than they do in a disk with a single rotation direction,' said Dr Impellizzeri.

'This could be a way in which a black hole can grow rapidly.'

The findings may explain how supermassive black holes — which existed even in the young universe — can develop in such short time frames. Pictured, NGC 1068, a spiral galaxy that lies around 47 million light years from the Earth, out in the direction of the constellation Cetus

For the present, the black hole's outer disk appears to be in a stable orbit around the inner disk, the researchers said.

'That will change when the outer disk begins to fall onto the inner disk, which may happen after a few orbits or a few hundred thousand years,' said Professor Gallimore.

'The rotating streams of gas will collide and become unstable, and the disks will likely collapse in a luminous event as the molecular gas falls into the black hole.'

'Unfortunately, we will not be there to witness the fireworks,' he lamented.

The full findings of the study were published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters.
